choices.text: Oral antihypertensive therapy
Platelet transfusion
Magnesium sulphate therapy and induction of labour
Intravenous immunoglobulin therapy

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida woman presents at 29 weeks gestation with headache and a blood pressure of 160/110 mm Hg. Investigations reveal 2+ proteinuria on dipstick, an elevated SGOT and SGPT and a platelet count of 80,000/mm3. What is the best management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Magnesium sulphate therapy and induction of labour

 

Even if hemolysis is not established, thrombocytopenia and elevated liver enzymes point toward severe features in pre eclampsia, which needs to be treated with Magnesium sulphate therapy and induction of labour 

 

  • HELLP syndrome is a complication of pre-eclampsia and includes
    • Hemolysis
    • Elevated liver enzymes
    • Thromobocytopenia
  • HELLP is an indication for termination of pregnancy.
  • MgSO4 also needs to be given for both seizure prophylaxis and will also provide neuro-protection of the neonate f/b delivery of the patient.

 

Severe features in pre eclampsia need to be started on magnesium sulphate therapy

 

 

 

Contraindications to Conservative management in severe preeclampsia (This means deliver asap in the following scenarios):

 

Remember by the mnemonic DELIVER Asap

D: Fetal Distress

E: Eclampsia

L: HELLP

I: DIC

V: non-viable fetus (extremely preterm)

E: pulmonary Edema

R: Renal failure

Asap: Abruption

 

Let's analyse each management option:

 

Option A. Oral Antihypertensive Therapy: While managing high blood pressure is crucial in preeclampsia, this option alone does not address the other severe features of the condition like proteinuria, liver dysfunction, and thrombocytopenia.

 

Option B. Platelet Transfusion: In the context of preeclampsia, platelet transfusion is not typically a primary management strategy unless there's a risk of severe bleeding or if surgery (like cesarean section) is planned and the platelet count is critically low.

 

Option C. Magnesium Sulphate Therapy and Induction of Labour: This is the correct option. Given the severity of symptoms and the potential risks to both the mother and the fetus, management often involves delivery (the definitive treatment for preeclampsia), along with magnesium sulphate to prevent eclamptic seizures.

 

Option D. Intravenous Immunoglobulin Therapy: IVIG is not a treatment for preeclampsia and does not address the immediate risks associated with this condition.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In cases with severe features, like significant hypertension, proteinuria, liver dysfunction, and thrombocytopenia, the primary management is to stabilize the mother and expedite delivery, as the condition typically resolves only after delivery. Magnesium sulphate is essential for seizure prophylaxis.

 

Ref: Page no 1852, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Deep tendon reflexes, urine output, Respiratory rate
Deep tendon reflexes, O2 saturation, consciousness status
O2 saturation, urine output, heart rate
Heart rate, BP, respiratory rate and urine output

questions.text: A 20-year primi presented at 32 weeks with eclampsia. She was started on MgSO4 (Pritchard’s regime) and she delivered after induction of labor. Maintenance dose of MgSO4 was continued for 24 hours. Prevention of Mg toxicity involves monitoring of the following clinical parameters:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Deep tendon reflexes, urine output, Respiratory rate

 

  • A woman on MgSO4 for management of eclampsia requires the following to be checked for Mg toxicity:
    1. Deep tendon reflexes
    2. Respiratory Rate
    3. Urine Output
  • Magnesium toxicity
    • At > 7-10 mEq/L: Loss of DTR
    • 10 - 12 mEq/L: Respiratory depression
    • 25 mEq/L: Cardiac arrest
  • Antidote: Ca gluconate (1 g IV)

 

Educational Objective

 

The prevention of magnesium toxicity in the management of eclampsia involves careful monitoring of deep tendon reflexes, urine output, and respiratory rate. Deep tendon reflexes help detect early signs of toxicity, urine output indicates renal function and magnesium clearance, and respiratory rate assesses potential respiratory depression from magnesium sulfate.

 

Ref: page no 439, Textbook of Obstetrics, Dr JB Sharma 1st edition

choices.text: Emergency Cesarean section.
Induction of labor
Prophylactic MgSO4
Urgent Ultrasound to see the fetal status

questions.text: A 22-year Primigravida presents at 34 weeks to the emergency with a BP of 160/110 mmHg. Her urine albumin is 3 +. She is complaining of headache and blurring of vision. On examination, the fetal heart cannot be auscultated. The uterus is relaxed, and a vaginal examination reveals a soft cervix which is 1 cm dilated and 30% effaced. You administer IV labetalol to lower her BP. What is the best immediate next line of management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Prophylactic MgSO4

 

  • This is a patient with severe preeclampsia with imminent eclampsia with intra-uterine fetal demise
  • She needs to be delivered but before that, the next best step would be to prevent eclampsia as she is having imminent signs (headache, blurring of vision)
  • Management of Preeclampsia:
  • Definitive treatment is delivery
  • Mild preeclampsia: Termination at 37 weeks
  • Severe preeclampsia
    • Admit; Consider prophylactic MgSO4
    • Start anti-hypertensives
    • Terminate at 37 weeks or SOS if
      • Persistent severe HTN 
    • Eclampsia, HELLP, pulmonary edema, ARF, DIC
    • Fetal compromise 
    • Abruption
    • Pre-viable fetus
  • Steroids (Betamethasone 12 mg 2 doses 24 h apart IM) for lung maturity if < 34 weeks

 

This is a patient with severe pre-eclampsia with imminent signs of eclampsia (since she has headache and blurring of vision)

 

  • The next best step would thus be prophylactic MgSO4 followed by Induction of Labor.

 

Let's analyse the options:

 

Option A. Emergency Cesarean Section: In cases of viable and distressed fetuses, an emergency Cesarean section could be a consideration. However, the indication for an emergency C-section in this scenario is unclear without confirmation of the current fetal status.

 

Option B. Induction of Labor: Induction of labor is generally considered when the fetus is viable and the condition of the mother or fetus necessitates delivery. In this scenario, the status of the fetus is not confirmed, and induction might not be the immediate next step without further assessment.

 

Option C. Prophylactic MgSO4: This is the correct answer. Given the signs of severe preeclampsia (high BP, proteinuria, headache, and vision changes), administering magnesium sulphate (MgSO4) is crucial for seizure prophylaxis (to prevent eclampsia). This step is important regardless of the fetal status.

 

Option D. Urgent Ultrasound to See the Fetal Status: While an ultrasound is important to assess fetal status, especially since the fetal heart sounds are not audible, the immediate management of severe preeclampsia takes precedence to prevent maternal complications like eclampsia.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Management of Preeclampsia:
  • Definitive treatment is delivery
  • Mild preeclampsia: Termination at 37 weeks
  • Severe preeclampsia
    • Admit; Consider prophylactic MgSO4
    • Start anti-hypertensives
    • Terminate at 37 weeks or SOS if
      • Persistent severe HTN 
    • Eclampsia, HELLP, pulmonary edema, ARF, DIC
    • Fetal compromise 
    • Abruption
    • Pre-viable fetus
  • Steroids (Betamethasone 12 mg 2 doses 24 h apart IM) for lung maturity if < 34 weeks

 

Ref: Page no 732, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Neuroprotection in preterm labor
Severe preeclampsia
Tocolysis
Severe IUGR

questions.text: Which is NOT an indication of using this drug in obstetrics?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Severe IUGR

 

MgSO4 is used for the following obstetric indications.

 

  1. Eclampsia & severe preeclampsia
  2. As a tocolytic in preterm labor
  3. For neuroprotection in very preterm

 

Let's review each option:

 

Option A. Neuroprotection in Preterm Labor: Magnesium sulphate is used as a neuroprotective agent for the fetus in cases of imminent preterm birth (before 32 weeks of gestation). It helps in reducing the risk of cerebral palsy and other neurological impairments in premature infants. This is an established indication for the use of magnesium sulfate in obstetrics.

 

Option B. Severe Preeclampsia: In cases of severe preeclampsia, magnesium sulfate is used for the prevention of seizures. It's a critical component of the management of severe preeclampsia and eclampsia.

 

Option C. Tocolysis: Tocolysis refers to the use of medication to suppress premature labor. Magnesium sulfate has been used off-label as a tocolytic agent to delay preterm labor, although it's not the first-line treatment for this purpose.

 

Option D. Severe IUGR (Intrauterine Growth Restriction): IUGR refers to poor growth of the fetus while in the mother's womb during pregnancy. The management of IUGR primarily focuses on monitoring and timely delivery. Magnesium sulfate has no role in the treatment or management of IUGR.

 

Educational Objective

 

MgSO4 is used for the following obstetric indications.

 

  1. Eclampsia & severe preeclampsia
  2. As a tocolytic in preterm labor
  3. For neuroprotection in very preterm

 

Ref: page no 439, Textbook of Obstetrics, Dr JB Sharma 1st edition

choices.text: An exaggerated diastolic notch is seen beyond 24 weeks on uterine artery Doppler in women at risk for developing pre-eclampsia.
A drop in levels of PAPP-A and PlGF is a predictor for preeclampsia.
Angiogenic factors sFlt-1 and s-Eng are decreased in women who are at risk of developing preeclampsia
Cell free DNA is increased in women who are at risk of developing preeclampsia due to accelerated apoptosis of cytotrophoblasts

questions.text: All are true regarding predictive tests for preeclampsia except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Angiogenic factors sFlt-1 and s-Eng are decreased in women who are at risk of developing preeclampsia

 

Predictors of preeclampsia:

 

  • Biophysical markers: Raised PI in the uterine Artery (11 – 14 weeks); notching of uterine Artery waveform (mid trimester).
  • Biochemical markers:

 

 

  • S-Flt-1 and s-Eng are Anti-angiogenic factors (Not angiogenic)
  • Roll over test: 28- 32 weeks: BP is measured with patient on her side first and then she is asked to roll on her back and BP is checked again -an increase of 20mmHg in diastolic BP from lateral to supine position is a positive test – 30% of such women will develop pre-eclampsia in the future. This test is not done anymore.
  • Angiotensin II sensitivity test: Rise in BP with Angiotensin II infusion.

 

**If the patient is at high risk of preeclampsia, low dose aspirin (75-150 mg/ day) should be started before 16 weeks of pregnancy to prevent early onset preeclampsia**

 

To understand which statement is not true regarding predictive tests for preeclampsia, let's evaluate each option:

 

Option A. An exaggerated diastolic notch is seen beyond 24 weeks on uterine artery Doppler in women at risk for developing pre-eclampsia: True. An exaggerated diastolic notch in the uterine artery Doppler waveform after 24 weeks of gestation is associated with an increased risk of developing preeclampsia. This finding indicates increased resistance in the uterine arteries.

 

Option B. A drop in levels of PAPP-A and PlGF is a predictor for preeclampsia.: True. Lower levels of Pregnancy-Associated Plasma Protein-A (PAPP-A) and Placental Growth Factor (PlGF) are associated with an increased risk of preeclampsia. These biomarkers are involved in placental development and function.

 

Option C. Angiogenic factors sFlt-1 and s-Eng are increased in women who are at risk of developing preeclampsia: False. Elevated levels of soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase-1 (sFlt-1) and soluble endoglin (s-Eng) are found in women at risk of developing preeclampsia. However, these are factors are anti-angiogenic and not angiogenic.

 

Option D. Cell free DNA is increased in women who are at risk of developing preeclampsia due to accelerated apoptosis of cytotrophoblasts: True. While cell-free DNA levels are increased in certain conditions during pregnancy, such as fetal chromosomal abnormalities (commonly assessed in non-invasive prenatal testing), its direct association with preeclampsia risk due to accelerated apoptosis of cytotrophoblasts is also mentioned in literature.

 

Educational Objective

 

Predictors of preeclampsia:

 

  • Biophysical markers: Raised PI in the uterine Artery (11 – 14 weeks); notching of uterine Artery waveform (mid trimester).
  • Biochemical markers:

 

 

  • S-Flt-1 and s-Eng are Anti-angiogenic factors (Not angiogenic)
  • Roll over test: 28- 32 weeks: BP is measured with patient on her side first and then she is asked to roll on her back and BP is checked again -an increase of 20mmHg in diastolic BP from lateral to supine position is a positive test – 30% of such women will develop pre-eclampsia in the future. This test is not done anymore.
  • Angiotensin II sensitivity test: Rise in BP with Angiotensin II infusion.

 

Ref: Page no 1818, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Low salt diet
Calcium supplementation started prior to 12 weeks
Aspirin 150 mg/ day prior to 16 weeks
Antioxidants – ascorbic acid and α-tocopherol prior to 12 weeks

questions.text: A 35-year primigravida is worried about her risk of developing preeclampsia. What is the single most important intervention to help reduce the risk in her?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Aspirin 150 mg/ day prior to 16 weeks

 

  • The RCOG and US preventive Services task force recommends low dose aspirin (up to 150mg/ day) prophylaxis for women at high risk for pre-eclampsia.
  • Aspirin is the ONLY recommended measure for prevention of pre-eclampsia

 

let's evaluate the proposed interventions:

 

Option A. Low Salt Diet: While general healthy eating is recommended during pregnancy, there's no strong evidence that a low salt diet specifically reduces the risk of preeclampsia. Traditional advice often suggested this, but recent studies have not supported it as an effective preventative measure for preeclampsia.

 

Option B. Calcium Supplementation Started Prior to 12 Weeks: Calcium supplementation can be beneficial in reducing the risk of preeclampsia, particularly in women with low dietary calcium intake. However, it's not typically highlighted as the primary preventive measure in women with a standard risk profile for preeclampsia.

 

Option C. Aspirin 150 mg/ day Prior to 16 Weeks: This is the correct answer. Low-dose aspirin (usually around 75-150 mg per day) started before 16 weeks of gestation has been shown to reduce the risk of preeclampsia, especially in women with certain risk factors. Aspirin helps by improving uteroplacental blood flow and reducing inflammation.

 

Option D. Antioxidants – Ascorbic Acid and α-tocopherol Prior to 12 Weeks: Although the theory behind using antioxidants like vitamin C (ascorbic acid) and vitamin E (α-tocopherol) to prevent preeclampsia is related to reducing oxidative stress, clinical trials have not consistently shown these supplements to be effective in reducing the risk of preeclampsia.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Low-dose aspirin started before 16 weeks of gestation is a recommended intervention to reduce the risk of developing preeclampsia, particularly for women at high risk.

 

Ref: Page no 1825, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Alpha-methyldopa
Captopril
Enalapril
Losartan

questions.text: Anti-hypertensives contra-indicated in pregnancy are all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Alpha-methyldopa

 

  • Anti-hypertensives:
    • DOC: Labetalol (Max oral dose 2400mg/d); can be given IV in emergencies (Max IV dose is 220 mg)
    • Alpha methyl dopa: Greatest safety data available, 48 h for onset of action
    • Nifedipine: CCB, short acting, oral (S/l is c/i) used in emergencies
    • Hydralazine: for emergencies, IV
    • Diuretics: only if pulmonary edema
    • Beta blockers: long term use causes Growth restriction, not preferred
    • ACE inhibitors and ARB – ABSOLUTE C/I in pregnancy as they cause fetal renal anomalies.

 

Let's evaluate the options provided:

 

Option A. Alpha-methyldopa: Alpha-methyldopa is considered safe and is one of the preferred antihypertensive medications during pregnancy. It has been widely used for many years without significant adverse effects on the fetus. Alpha-methyldopa is not contraindicated in pregnancy.

 

Option B. Captopril: Captopril, an ACE inhibitor, is contraindicated in pregnancy, especially in the second and third trimesters, due to the risk of fetal renal dysplasia, oligohydramnios, and other complications.

 

Option C. Enalapril: Enalapril is another ACE inhibitor, and like captopril, it is contraindicated in pregnancy for the same reasons.

 

Option D. Losartan: Losartan is an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) and is also contraindicated in pregnancy. ARBs have been associated with adverse fetal outcomes similar to those of ACE inhibitors.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • The anti-hypertensive drug of choice in pregnancy is labetalol
  • Alpha-methyldopa is considered safe and is one of the preferred anti hypertensives in pregnancy.
  • However, ACE inhibitors (like captopril and enalapril) and ARBs (like losartan) are contraindicated due to their potential adverse effects on the developing fetus.

 

Ref: Page no 438, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Dhaka regime
Sibai regime
Magpie regime
Zuspan regime

questions.text: All are regimes of MgSO4 for treatment of eclampsia except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Magpie regime

 

Various regimes of MgSO4 for eclampsia:

 

  1. Pritchard Regime (most commonly used in India)
    • Initial dose: 20% MgSo4- 4g IV slowly over 4 mins (1g/min) as 20 ml followed by 5g in each buttock as 10ml of 50%MgSO4
    • Maintenance dose: 5g of 50% MgSO4 IM in alternate buttocks 4 hourly till 24 h or till delivery, whichever is later.
  2. Sibai regime:
    • Loading dose 6g MgSO4 IV over 15 – 20 mins f/b IV infusion 2g/ h as maintenance dose
    • Recommended by ACOG
  3. Zuspan Regime
    • Loading dose 4g IV MgSO4 f/b IV infusion of 1g/ h until 24 h after delivery
  4. Dhaka regime
    • Lower dose of MgSO4 (Half of Pritchard’s)
    • Loading dose is 4g IV over 15 mins
    • Following this, 3 g MgSO4 IM in each buttock 4 hourly for 24 h after administration of 1st dose.
    • This regime was developed with South-East Asian women’s smaller body habitus in mind to reduce the risk of Mg toxicity as compared to Pritchard regime.

 

Magpie is not a regime. It was a large multicentric study to determine the usefulness of MgSO4 for prophylaxis for eclampsia in women with severe preeclampsia

 

Educational Objective

 

  • The key educational takeaway is that while there are several recognized regimens for the administration of magnesium sulfate in the management of eclampsia (like the Dhaka, Sibai, and Zuspan regimens), the "Magpie regime" is not one of them.
  • Instead, the Magpie Trial was a significant research study that helped establish the effectiveness of magnesium sulfate in this context.

 

 

Ref: page no 439, Textbook of Obstetrics, Dr JB Sharma 1st edition

choices.text: Preeclampsia
Chronic hypertension with superimposed preeclampsia
Eclampsia
Gestational hypertension

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida at 39 weeks has a BP recording of 150/100 which when repeated is the same. Her baseline BP during earlier visits was 120/80 mmHg. She does not complain of headache/ blurring of vision or epigastric pain. Abdominal exam reveals a term uterus with cephalic presentation and FHR of 140 bpm. Urine albumin is nil. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Gestational hypertension 

 

  • Hypertension in pregnancy is defined as blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg or greater on at least two separate occasions that are 6 h or more apart. The presence of edema is no longer used as a diagnostic criterion because it is so prevalent in normal pregnant women. A rise in systolic blood pressure of 30 mmHg and a rise in diastolic blood pressure of 15 mmHg are also no longer used.
  • In gestational hypertension, maternal blood pressure reaches 140/90 or greater for the first time during pregnancy, and proteinuria is not present. In preeclampsia, blood pressure increases to 140/90 after 20 weeks of gestation and proteinuria is present (300 mg in 24 h or 1+ protein or greater on dipstick). Eclampsia is present when women with preeclampsia develop seizures.
  • Chronic hypertension is defined as BP >140/90 mmHg before pregnancy or diagnosed before 20 weeks of gestation, or hypertension first diagnosed after 20 weeks of gestation and persistent after 12 weeks postpartum.
  • A woman with hypertension who develops preeclampsia is described as having chronic hypertension with superimposed preeclampsia.

 

Let's analyse each option based on the provided scenario:

 

Option A. Preeclampsia: In this case, the woman does not have proteinuria or other systemic symptoms, making preeclampsia less likely.

 

Option B. Chronic Hypertension with Superimposed Preeclampsia: The patient's baseline BP was normal during earlier visits, which does not suggest chronic hypertension.

 

Option C. Eclampsia: There is no mention of seizures or convulsions in this scenario, ruling out eclampsia.

 

Option D. Gestational Hypertension: This is the correct diagnosis. The woman has new-onset hypertension at 39 weeks without proteinuria or other symptoms suggestive of preeclampsia.

 

Educational Objective:  Gestational hypertension is characterized by new-onset hypertension after 20 weeks of gestation without proteinuria or other systemic findings associated with preeclampsia.

 

Ref: page 1780, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Hemolysis
Elevated liver enzymes
Thrombocytopenia
Retroplacental hemorrhage

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of HELLP syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Retroplacental hemorrhage 

 

HELLP Syndrome

 

  • It is an acronym for Hemolysis (H), Elevated liver enzymes (EL) and Low Platelet count (LP) of < 1,00,000/mm3
  • It is a rare complication of pregnancy induced hypertension.
  • It may be associated even with mild hypertension and proteinuria

 

Clinical Features:

 

  • Manifested by nausea, vomiting, epigastric or right upper quadrant pain, along with biochemical and hematological changes.
  • Parenchymal necrosis of liver causes elevation in hepatic enzymes (AST and ALT > 70 IU/L and LDH > 600 IU/L).
  • There may be subcapsular hematoma formation (which may need CT scanning) and abnormal peripheral smear.
  • Eventually liver may rupture to cause sudden hypotension, due to hemoperitoneum.

 

Let's evaluate each option to identify the one that is not a part of HELLP syndrome:

 

Option A. Hemolysis: Hemolysis refers to the breakdown of red blood cells, which is a key feature of HELLP syndrome.

 

Option B. Elevated Liver Enzymes: Elevated liver enzymes indicate liver dysfunction, which is another essential component of HELLP syndrome.

 

Option C. Thrombocytopenia: Thrombocytopenia is a significant reduction in platelet count, which is the third critical component of HELLP syndrome

 

Option D. Retroplacental Hemorrhage: This is the correct answer. Retroplacental haemorrhage, also known as placental abruption, is a separate obstetric complication that involves the detachment of the placenta from the uterine wall before delivery. While it can be a serious condition, it is not a part of HELLP syndrome.

 

Educational Objective

 

HELLP Syndrome

 

  • It is an acronym for Hemolysis (H), Elevated liver enzymes (EL) and Low Platelet count (LP) of < 1,00,000/mm3
  • It is a rare complication of pregnancy induced hypertension.
  • It may be associated even with mild hypertension and proteinuria

 

Ref: Page no 1849, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Conservative management with anti-hypertensives
Delivery after 34 weeks of gestation
Immediate delivery
Declare fetal demise

questions.text: A Primigravida presents at 32 weeks with pre-eclampsia. She complains of decreased fetal movements. An umbilical artery Doppler is done which is as shown in the image. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Immediate delivery

 

  • The given UA Doppler shows reversal of end diastolic flow, which is suggestive of impending fetal demise – so the immediate management is Delivery

 

Let's evaluate each option:

 

Option A. Conservative Management with Anti-Hypertensives: While controlling maternal hypertension is important in pre-eclampsia, the primary concern in this scenario is the well-being of the fetus due to decreased movements. Conservative management alone may not address the fetal distress.

 

Option B. Delivery After 34 Weeks of Gestation: The decision to delay delivery depends on the overall condition of both the mother and the fetus. Reversal of diastolic flow shows fetal distress and waiting until 34 weeks may not be appropriate.

 

Option C. Immediate Delivery: In the presence of pre-eclampsia, decreased fetal movements and doppler suggestive of reversal of flow, immediate delivery is often indicated to ensure the well-being of the fetus.

 

Option D. Declare Fetal Demise: This statement is not true. Immediate delivery can prevent fetal demise

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Immediate delivery is often indicated when there are signs of fetal distress, as it is essential to ensure the well-being of the fetus.  
  • Reversal of diastolic flow in the umbilical artery  raises concerns about fetal compromise, and immediate  delivery is crucial

 

Ref:  Page no 1840, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

a, d, e

questions.text:
Which of the following are feature(s) of magnesium toxicity in pregnancy?

 

  1. Loss of deep tendon reflex
  2. Decreased respiratory rate
  3. Decreased urine output
  4. Hypertension
  5. Increased heart rate
questions.solution:
Ans. C. a, b

 

Features of Mg Toxicity are

 

  • Loss of deep tendon reflex (Depression of patellar reflex is the earliest sign of patellar toxicity): Earliest Sign
  • Decreased respiratory rate (<12 per minute)
  • Chest pain, heart block, pulmonary edema
  • Cardiac arrest
  • O2 saturation monitoring (PaO2 < 95%)
  • Double vision
  • Slurred speech
  • Nausea-vomiting
  • Muscular weakness

 

**Decreased urine output is not a feature of Mg toxicity. Renal failure can be seen in severe preeclampsia/ eclampsia and as Mg is excreted through the kidneys, decreased renal function can increase the Mg levels in the blood thereby leading to Mg toxicity.

 

Thus Option C) is correct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Features of Magnesium Toxicity:

 

  • Loss of deep tendon reflex (Depression of patellar reflex is the earliest sign of patellar toxicity): Earliest Sign
  • Decreased respiratory rate (<12 per minute)
  • Chest pain, heart block, pulmonary edema
  • Cardiac arrest
  • O2 saturation monitoring (PaO2 < 95%)
  • Double vision
  • Slurred speech
  • Nausea-vomiting
  • Muscular weakness

 

**Decreased urine output is not a feature of Mg toxicity. Renal failure can be seen in severe preeclampsia/ eclampsia and as Mg is excreted through the kidneys, decreased renal function can increase the Mg levels in the blood thereby leading to Mg toxicity.

 

Ref: Page no 1880, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: FBS & PPBS
HBA1C
Urine routine for sugar
GCT

questions.text: A 34-year Primigravida presents to the antenatal OPD. Her mother is a diabetic and she is screened for Diabetes at her 8 weeks antenatal visit. What was the most likely screening method used?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. HBA1C

 

  • As per IADPSG guidelines, testing for Diabetes in the first trimester of pregnancy is by HBA1c or an FBS or RBS.  (For Overt diabetes Hba1C > 6.5 % or FBS >126 mg/dl or RBS >200 mg/dl)
  • Urine for sugar is not sensitive for testing for Diabetes in pregnancy as physiologic glycosuria can be present
  • GCT is not used for Diabetes screening in the first trimester. It is part of screening of GDM between 24 – 28 weeks.

 

Let's look at each option separately :

 

Option A. FBS & PPBS: FBS and PPBS are essential for monitoring blood sugar levels in pregnant women, but both together may typically be performed later in pregnancy or when there is suspicion of gestational diabetes. IADPSG Consensus Panel members favored use of any available certified laboratory measure of glucose (Fasting OR Random plasma glucose OR Hb A1C) for initial detection of possible cases.

 

Option B. HBA1C (Hemoglobin A1C): HBA1C is a blood test that provides an average of a person's blood sugar levels over the past two to three months. It is a valuable screening tool for diabetes, including in pregnant women. HBA1C can be used as an early screening method for diabetes in pregnant women, especially when there is a family history of diabetes.

 

Option C. Urine Routine for Sugar: Urine routine for sugar is not the primary method for diabetes screening in pregnant women. It may be used for general monitoring but is less reliable than blood tests.

 

Option D. GCT (Glucose Challenge Test): GCT is typically performed later in pregnancy to screen for gestational diabetes and is not the primary method for early screening in the first trimester.

 

Educational Objective (Summary):

 

Hemoglobin A1C (HBA1C) is the most likely screening method used for diabetes at the 8-week antenatal visit, especially when there is a family history of diabetes. It provides a longer-term view of blood sugar control.

 

Ref: Page 1108, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Anemia
Antepartum hemorrhage
Gestational Diabetes mellitus
Thrombocytopenia

questions.text: An infant was born at 36 weeks of pregnancy with a birthweight 4.5 kg as shown in the image.  Which of the following conditions is associated with this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Gestational Diabetes mellitus

 

The clinical scenario shown is of macrosomia.

Macrosomia is defined as estimated fetal weight > 90th percentile for that gestational age

 

  • Causes of macrosomia are.
    • Gestational Diabetes mellitus
    • Maternal obesity
    • Previous baby with macrosomia
    • Post-term pregnancy
    • Excessive weight gain in pregnancy
  • Anemia and APH are associated with fetal growth restriction
  • Thrombocytopenia has no association with fetal weight

 

Let's briefly explain each option:

 

Option A. Anemia: Anemia refers to a deficiency of hemoglobin in the blood and is not typically associated with macrosomia or a large birthweight.

 

Option B. Antepartum hemorrhage: Antepartum hemorrhage refers to bleeding during pregnancy before the onset of labor and is not directly associated with the infant's birthweight.

 

Option C. Gestational Diabetes Mellitus (GDM): Infants born to mothers with GDM are at an increased risk of macrosomia, which can have implications for both mother and baby. Proper management of GDM during pregnancy is essential to reduce the risk of complications.

 

Option D. Thrombocytopenia: Thrombocytopenia is a condition characterized by a low platelet count in the blood and is not directly related to the infant's birthweight.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The birth of an infant with a birthweight of 4.5 kg at 36 weeks of pregnancy is suggestive of macrosomia.
  • Macrosomia is commonly associated with maternal gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM), which can lead to larger birthweights in babies.

choices.text: ≥ 110 mg/dl
≥ 126 mg/dl
≥ 140 mg/dl
≥ 200 mg/dl

questions.text: For diagnosis of overt gestational diabetes, the fasting blood sugar (FBS] level should be?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. ≥ 126 mg/dl 

 

IADPSG Recommendations: Testing in 2 phases

 

1st Phase: To test for overt diabetes (which the woman may be unaware of)
 

  • Done in the 1st trimester (early antenatal visit)
  • Test using HbA1C/ FBS/ RBS
  • FBS ≥ 126 mg/dL
  • HbA1C ≥ 6.5 %
  • RBS ≥ 200 mg/dL (but this should be confirmed by FBS/ HbA1C)

 

                       

 

2nd Phase: To test for GDM
 

  • Done between 24 – 28 weeks
  • 75g GTT
  • Fasting: 92/ 1h – 180/ 2h – 153
  • Any one value abnormal: Enough to diagnose GDM

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To diagnose overt gestational diabetes, the fasting blood sugar (FBS) level should be ≥ 126 mg/dl (milligrams per decilitre).
  • It's important to note that the diagnostic criteria for gestational diabetes may vary in different guidelines and regions. However, a fasting blood sugar level of ≥ 126 mg/dl is a commonly recognized threshold for diagnosing overt gestational diabetes.

 

 

Ref: Page 1108, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

37 weeks

questions.text: A 34-year Primi who is a known diabetic on insulin presents at 34 weeks pregnancy.  On examination, the uterus is 34 weeks and FHR is 140 bpm. Her blood sugar is well controlled. At what period of gestation should her delivery be planned?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 38 weeks

 

In Overt Diabetes (Pre-gestational diabetes) on insulin, Plan delivery at 38 weeks OR earlier if

 

  • Poorly controlled sugars
  • Non reassuring fetal status

 

In Gestational Diabetes
 

  • Plan delivery at 40 weeks
  • Avoid past dates
  • Anticipate shoulder dystocia
  • Prophylactic LSCS in diabetic women if estimated fetal weight > 4.5 Kg

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In Overt Diabetes (Pre-gestational diabetes) on insulin, delivery is planned at 38 weeks.
  • Earlier delivery may be planned if there are poorly controlled sugars or non-reassuring fetal status

 

Ref: Page no 1107, Williams Obstetrics, Page no 509, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Dutta

choices.text: Insulin secretion increases in pregnancy
Insulin resistance is due to placental hormones
Maternal insulin can cross the placenta
The fetus starts secreting insulin at 12 weeks

questions.text: All are true regarding physiology of pregnancy except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Maternal insulin can cross the placenta

 

Carbohydrate metabolism in pregnancy

 

  • Pregnancy is a diabetogenic state associated with hyperinsulinemia and insulin resistance
  • Insulin resistance is due to placental hormones (human placental lactogen, estrogen, progesterone, cortisol)
  • Insulin secretion increases during pregnancy
  • Insulin resistance is maximum between 24-28 weeks of pregnancy
  • Maternal insulin cannot cross the placenta
  • The fetus starts secreting insulin by 12 weeks

 

Let's explore each of the given options:

 

  1. Insulin Secretion Increases in Pregnancy (Option A): True. During pregnancy, the body's need for insulin increases due to the greater demand for glucose by both the mother and the growing fetus. The pancreas typically responds by increasing insulin production to meet these needs.
     
  2. Insulin Resistance is Due to Placental Hormones (Option B): This statement is also true. Pregnancy is characterized by a state of insulin resistance, which worsens as pregnancy progresses. This insulin resistance is primarily driven by placental hormones such as human placental lactogen, progesterone, and others. These hormones ensure that enough glucose is available for the fetus by making the mother's body less responsive to insulin.
     
  3. Maternal Insulin Can Cross the Placenta (Answer C): This is false, and therefore the correct answer. Maternal insulin does not cross the placenta. The fetus produces its own insulin starting from around 10-12 weeks of gestation. The mother's insulin does not enter the fetal circulation; instead, the glucose crosses the placenta, and the fetus produces insulin in response to this glucose.
     
  4. The Fetus Starts Securing Insu lin at 12 Weeks (Option D): This is a true statement. The fetal pancreas begins to function and produce insulin around the 12th week of gestation. Fetal insulin plays a crucial role in fetal growth and development, especially in the second and third trimesters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnancy, there is an increase in insulin secretion due to increased insulin resistance, largely driven by placental hormones. However, maternal insulin does not cross the placenta; the fetus produces its own insulin in response to glucose that crosses from the maternal circulation.

 

Ref: Page 66, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Pre-gestational diabetes
Gestational diabetes mellitus
Effect of valproate
Hypertensive on ACE inhibitors

questions.text: Identify the maternal condition that can lead to the findings in the baby as shown below
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Pre-gestational diabetes

 

  • This image is mermaid syndrome or sirenomelia
  • It is characteristically associated with overt (pre-gestational) Diabetes mellitus.
  • The most common anomaly associated with overt (pre-gestational) diabetes mellitus in pregnancy is cardiac anomalies (VSD being the most common).

 

Let's examine each of the options:

 

  1. Pre-gestational Diabetes: This refers to diabetes that exists before pregnancy. Women with pre-gestational diabetes have a higher risk of giving birth to babies with congenital anomalies, including neural tube defects and cardiovascular malformations.
     
  2. Gestational Diabetes Mellitus (GDM): This type of diabetes develops during pregnancy and generally resolves after delivery. While GDM can lead to several complications, such as macrosomia or hypoglycemia in the baby, it is not typically associated with congenital anomalies.
     
  3. Effect of Valproate: Valproate use during pregnancy, particularly in the first trimester, is associated with an increased risk of several congenital malformations, including neural tube defects, cleft palate, and heart defects.
     
  4. Hypertensive on ACE Inhibitors: ACE inhibitors are not recommended during pregnancy, as they can lead to fetal complications such as renal damage. However, there is no known association between the use of ACE inhibitors and sirenomelia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mermaid syndrome or sirenomelia is characteristically associated with overt (pre-gestational) Diabetes mellitus.
  • The most common anomaly associated with pre-gestational diabetes mellitus in pregnancy is cardiac anomalies (VSD being the most common).

 

Ref: Page 1110, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Glyburide
Insulin
Metformin
Pioglitazone

questions.text: Which hypoglycemic drug cannot be used in diabetes in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Pioglitazone

 

Drugs safe in pregnancy are:

 

OHA – Metformin (Category B) and Glyburide (Category C) and Insulin

 

  • Both Metformin and Glyburide cross the placenta
  • Metformin:
    • Biguanide, acts by promoting glucose uptake in the periphery and the liver
    • Suppresses hepatic glucose production
    • Hypoglycemia not seen
    • Started at 250 mg TDs; Max: 2500 mg/day
  • Glyburide
    • Increases insulin secretion
    • Safe after 15 weeks
    • Dose: 2.5 mg BD; may 20 mg/ day
    • Increased incidence of neonatal and maternal hypoglycemia with glyburide

 

Let's discuss each option:

 

  1. Glyburide: Glyburide is a sulfonylurea class of medication that increases insulin secretion from the pancreas. It is classified as Category C by the FDA, meaning that animal reproduction studies have shown an adverse effect on the fetus and there are no adequate and well-controlled studies in humans, but potential benefits may warrant use of the drug in pregnant women despite potential risks. Glyburide does cross the placenta but has been used in pregnancy, particularly in the second and third trimesters. However, it may increase the risk of neonatal and maternal hypoglycemia.
     
  2. Insulin: Insulin is the most common and preferred treatment for managing diabetes in pregnancy, especially if the diabetes is pre-gestational. It does not cross the placenta and therefore does not pose a direct risk to the fetal development. Different types of insulin can be used to manage blood sugar levels effectively during pregnancy.
     
  3. Metformin: Metformin is a biguanide that decreases hepatic glucose production and increases glucose uptake in the periphery. Classified as Category B by the FDA, it suggests that there is no evidence of risk in human pregnancy. Metformin does cross the placenta, but studies have not shown an increased risk of birth defects or other pregnancy complications. It's often used in gestational diabetes and in women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) who are trying to conceive.
     
  4. Pioglitazone (Answer D): Pioglitazone belongs to the thiazolidinedione class of drugs, which is generally not recommended during pregnancy. The safety of pioglitazone in pregnancy has not been established, and there are concerns about its potential effects on the fetus. Therefore, it is usually avoided in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When treating diabetes in pregnancy, insulin is the preferred medication due to its safety profile.
     
  • Metformin and glyburide can also be used, albeit with some caution and monitoring.
     
  • Pioglitazone, on the other hand, is not recommended for use during pregnancy due to the lack of sufficient safety data and potential fetal risks.

 

Ref: Page no 1110, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Necrotizing enterocolitis
Hyperbilirubinemia
Neonatal hypocalcemia
Neonatal hyperglycemia

questions.text: A 32-years old G3P2L2 visits an antenatal clinic at 28 weeks. She reveals during history that her first baby weighed 4.6 kg, second baby weighed 4.8 kg, and both were delivered by C-section. Neonatal complications of an infant of diabetic mother except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D.  Neonatal hyperglycemia

 

Diabetes mellitus during pregnancy

 

Neonatal complications (Seen because of Pedersen Hypothesis)

 

  • Hypoglycemia
  • Respiratory distress syndrome
  • Hyperbilirubinemia
  • Necrotizing enterocolitis
  • Polycythemia
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Cardiomyopathy

 

Let's discuss the neonatal complications associated with infants of diabetic mothers, to understand why "Neonatal hyperglycemia" is the exception:

 

  1. Necrotizing Enterocolitis (Option A): While not the most common complication in infants of diabetic mothers, necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) can occur. NEC is a serious intestinal disease that affects mostly premature infants. Infants of diabetic mothers are at risk for various complications, but NEC is not typically a direct consequence of maternal diabetes.
     
  2. Hyperbilirubinemia (Option B): This is a common complication in infants of diabetic mothers. These infants often have increased red blood cell turnover, which can lead to higher levels of bilirubin and result in jaundice.
     
  3. Neonatal Hypocalcaemia (Option C): Infants of diabetic mothers are at an increased risk of hypocalcemia, or low calcium levels in the blood. This can occur due to various metabolic imbalances associated with the maternal diabetic environment.
     
  4. Neonatal Hyperglycemia (Answer D): This is less likely in infants of diabetic mothers and thus is the correct answer. In fact, neonatal hypoglycemia is a more common issue in these infants. Due to high insulin levels in response to maternal hyperglycemia, these infants can have low blood sugar levels after birth once the maternal glucose supply is cut off.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neonatal complications (Seen because of Pedersen Hypothesis)

 

  • Hypoglycemia
  • Respiratory distress syndrome
  • Hyperbilirubinemia
  • Necrotizing enterocolitis
  • Polycythemia
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Cardiomyopathy

 

Ref: Page no 1102, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Acute fatty liver of pregnancy
HELLP syndrome
Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy
Acute viral hepatitis

questions.text: A pregnant woman in her second trimester presents with mildly elevated liver enzymes and itching over her body. She has no history of liver disease. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy

 

Explanation: Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy typically presents in the second or third trimester with itching and elevated liver enzymes but without significant liver damage. It's characterized by impaired bile flow and can lead to adverse fetal outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy: This is diagnosed by the Swansea criteria. Patients with AFLP usually present in the 3rd trimester with jaundice, abdominal pain, vomiting. There is altered liver function along with worsening renal and coagulation parameters. Hypoglycemia is typically seen.
  • Option B: HELLP Syndrome: This is a form of severe preeclampsia so a h/o high BP would usually be mentioned. HELLP syndrome is a triad of Hemolysis, Elevated Liver Enzymes and Low Platelets.
  • Option D: Acute viral hepatitis: This can be seen in any trimester. There is a history of fever, constitutional symptoms and jaundice. Serum bilirubin is raised and AST and ALT are very highly raised.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference- Page no 270, DC Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition

choices.text: It is associated with high fetal and maternal morbidity and mortality

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Acute fatty liver of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. It is associated with high fetal and maternal morbidity and mortality 

 

  • Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy-
  • The most frequent cause of acute liver failure during pregnancy
  • 1 in 10000 pregnancies
  • Recurrence – rare

 

AFLP is diagnosed by Swansea criteria where 6 out of 14 criteria are required to diagnose AFLP

AFLP: Swansea diagnostic criteria

(Six or more in the absence of other explanation)

  • Vomiting
  • Abdominal pain
  • Polydipsia/polyuria
  • Encephalopathy
  • High bilirubin > 15 micromol/L
  • Hypoglycemia < 4 mmol/L
  • High uric acid > 340 micromol/L
  • Leukocytosis > 11x106/L
  • Ascites or bright liver on ultrasound
  • High AST/ALT > 42 micromol/L
  • High ammonia >47 micromol/L
  • Renal impairment with creatinine > 150 micromol/L
  • Coagulopathy PT > 14 sec
  • Microvesicular steatosis on liver biopsy

 

Reference- Williams Obstetrics 25th edition, Page no 1061

choices.text: Kidney increases in pregnancy by about 1.5 cm
Pelvicalyceal dilatation is more on the left side than the right side
An increased GFR leads to lower serum creatinine levels
Glycosuria may be seen in up to 50% of pregnant women

questions.text: Which is not seen in pregnancy regarding renal changes in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B.  Pelvicalyceal dilatation is more on the left side than right side

Physiological changes in the urinary system in pregnancy

  1. Kidneys
    1. Increase in size by about 1.5 cm
    2. Pelvicalyceal dilatation (Right > left)
    3. Increased GFR leading to low creatinine, low BUN and low urea levels
    4. Total volume of urine passed is normal
    5. Enzyme renin is increased
  2. Ureter
    1. Atonic, dilated (Right > left)
  3. Bladder
    1. Mucosa become hyperemic and congested
    2. Increased frequency in the 1st and 3rd trimester
    3. SUI due to urethral sphincter weakness and decreased bladder capacity
  4. Glycosuria
    1. May be seen in up to 50% of pregnant women due to increase in GFR and decreases tubular reabsorption of glucose lowering the renal threshold
  5. Proteinuria
    1. Significant proteinuria (> 300mg/24h) is seen in preeclampsia

Ref: Page no 55, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma

choices.text: It is the most common cause of jaundice in pregnancy
Itching is typically present on the palms and soles
The recurrence rate in subsequent pregnancies is up to 50%
It is associated with meconium staining of amniotic fluid and fetal death

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding Obstetric Cholestasis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. It is the most common cause of jaundice in pregnancy

 

Obstetric Cholestasis-

  • 2nd most common cause of jaundice in pregnancy (after viral hepatitis)

Clinical Features-

  • Commonly presents in the: 3rd trimester
  • Pruritus

 

Main symptom

  • Generalized but more common on soles and palms
  • Most severe at night
  • Slight jaundice; Associated dark urine, pale stools, steatorrhea and malaise may be seen

 

Investigations-

  • Mildly raised SGOT/ SGPT (usually less than 500)
  • Moderately elevated ALP (Alkaline phosphatase)
  • Moderately elevated serum bilirubin (up to 5 mg %)
  • Raised serum bile acids
      • Most specific investigation
      • Values > 10µmol/L – indicative of increased levels;
      • Values > 40µmol/L – associated with poor perinatal outcome
  • Effect on Pregnancy -
  • Meconium-stained amniotic fluid; Fetal distress; Stillbirths; Increased perinatal mortality rate
  • Management-
  • Symptomatic relief
      • Emollients
      • Antihistamine
      • Ursodeoxycholic acid: Relieves pruritus, lowers bile acid and serum liver enzyme levels
  • Obstetric Management
      • Monitoring with weekly Liver function test
      • If PT-INR prolonged – offer vitamin K
      • Induction of Labor at 38 weeks can be considered.
      • Antepartum and Intrapartum fetal monitoring

 

  • Post Delivery
    • Repeat LFT at 6 weeks postpartum
    • Avoid Estrogen containing contraceptives
    • Recurrence rate in subsequent pregnancy: high (50 – 60%)

 

Reference-: Page 1059, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Immediate induction of labor
Emergency LSCS

Weekly LFT and plan delivery at 38 weeks

questions.text: A 27-year G2P1L1 presents at 33 weeks with itching mainly on the palms of her hands. The itching worsens at night. She gives a similar history in her 1st pregnancy. On examination, her BP is 130/84 mmHg. There is mild icterus and abdominal examination reveals a 32 weeks uterus with fetal heart rate of 140 bpm. Her SGOT is 112 IU/L, SGPT is 124 IU/L and serum bilirubin is 2 mg%. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Weekly LFT and plan delivery at 38 weeks

 

The diagnosis is Obstetric cholestasis

 

Management

    • Symptomatic relief: mollients, Antihistamine, Ursodeoxycholic acid (Relieves pruritus, lowers bile acid and serum liver enzyme levels)
    • Obstetric Management
  • Monitoring with weekly LFT, PT-INR
  • If PT-INR prolonged – offer vitamin K
  • Induction of Labor at 38 weeks
  • Antepartum and Intrapartum fetal monitoring

Reference: - Williams Obstetrics 25th edition, Page no 1060

≥ 30 mg/24 h
