questions.text: To define preeclampsia, the proteinuria defined is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. ≥ 300 mg/ 24 h

 

  • Pre-eclampsia is defined as Hypertension plus
    • Proteinuria ≥ 300 mg/ 24h or
    • Urine protein: creatinine ratio ≥ 0.3 or
    • Dipstick 1+ or more
  • But remember, for severity of preeclampsia, proteinuria is no longer a parameter

 

Educational Objective

 

The diagnosis of preeclampsia involves assessing for the presence of hypertension and significant proteinuria, defined as the excretion of 300 mg or more of protein in a 24-hour urine collection.

 

Ref: Page no 712, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: The diagnosis is made if BP > 140/90 mmHg after 20 weeks in the absence of proteinuria
5-10% of eclamptic seizures develop in women with gestational hypertension
The diagnosis is made only if the blood pressure does not return to normal after 12 weeks postpartum
It is also known as transient hypertension as the BP returns to normal postpartum

questions.text: All are true regarding gestational hypertension except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. The diagnosis is made only if the blood pressure does not return to normal after 12 weeks postpartum

 

  • Gestational hypertension is defined as hypertension in the absence of proteinuria > 20 weeks.
  • The BP returns to normal after 12 weeks postpartum and is hence also known by some as transient hypertension
  • 10% of eclampsia cases is seen in women with gestational HTN

 

Classification of HTN in pregnancy

 

 

Let's examine each statement to identify which one is not true about gestational hypertension:

 

Option A. The Diagnosis is Made if BP > 140/90 mmHg after 20 Weeks in the Absence of Proteinuria: True. Gestational hypertension is diagnosed when a pregnant woman has blood pressure higher than 140/90 mmHg after 20 weeks of gestation, without the presence of significant proteinuria.

 

Option B. 5-10% of Eclamptic Seizures Develop in Women with Gestational Hypertension: This statement is misleading. While women with gestational hypertension have an increased risk of developing preeclampsia, which can lead to eclampsia, the exact percentage risk of eclamptic seizures in women with gestational hypertension alone is not well-defined.

 

 

Option C. The Diagnosis is Made Only if the Blood Pressure Does Not Return to Normal after 12 Weeks Postpartum: False. This statement is incorrect. Gestational hypertension is characterized by high blood pressure during pregnancy that usually resolves postpartum. If high blood pressure persists after 12 weeks postpartum, it suggests chronic hypertension rather than gestational hypertension.

 

Option D. It is Also Known as Transient Hypertension as the BP Returns to Normal Postpartum: True. Gestational hypertension is often referred to as transient hypertension of pregnancy because in most cases, the blood pressure normalizes after the delivery of the baby.

 

Educational Objective

 

 

Ref: page no 711, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: 7 mEq/L
10 mEq/L
12 mEq/L
14 mEq/L

questions.text: Patellar reflexes disappear when the plasma magnesium level reaches:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 10 mEq/L

 

  • Eclamptic convulsions are almost always prevented or arrested by plasma magnesium levels maintained at 4 – 7 mEq/L (Equivalent to 4.8 -8.4 mg/dl or 2.0 – 3.5 mmol/L)
  • In women on MgSO4 for treatment of eclampsia/ severe pre-eclampsia, they have to be monitored very carefully for signs of Mg toxicity
  • Mg toxicity is a cause for concern

 

 

  • Remember: Disappearance of Deep tendon (Patellar) reflexes are the 1st sign of Mg toxicity
  • Antidote: Calcium gluconate or calcium chloride – 1 g IV
  • Monitoring of patient on MgSO4: Check
    1. Patellar reflex
    2. Respiratory Rate
    3. Urine output (Mg is excreted through the kidneys, so ARF can impair Mg excretion leading to Mg toxicity)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Monitoring for magnesium toxicity is crucial when administering magnesium sulfate, especially in obstetric settings for conditions like preeclampsia or eclampsia.
  • The loss of deep tendon reflexes, such as the patellar reflex, is the first clinical sign and usually occurs at plasma magnesium levels around 10 mEq/L.

choices.text: Amlodipine
Labetalol
Captopril
Nifedipine

questions.text: A 25-year-old P2L2 had just delivered following induction for severe preeclampsia. Her BP on the 2nd postnatal day is 160/100mmHg. Which anti-hypertensive should be avoided in a breastfeeding mother?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Amlodipine

 

  • Antihypertensive agents with no known adverse effects on infants receiving breast milk: Mnemonic: ECLAM-N
    • Enalapril
    • Captopril
    • Labetalol
    • Atenolol
    • Metoprolol
    • Nifedipine
  • Antihypertensive agents with insufficient evidence on infant safety in breast-feeding (not recommended in breast feeding mothers):
    • Angiotensin receptor blocking agents
    • Amlodipine
    • ACE-Inhibitors (Except enalapril and captopril)

 

Let's review each option:

 

Option A. Amlodipine: Amlodipine, a calcium channel blocker, is generally not the preferred choice in breastfeeding mothers. This is the correct answer. Given the limited data and the existence of safer alternatives, amlodipine is often avoided or used with caution in breastfeeding mothers.

 

Option B. Labetalol: Labetalol, a beta-blocker, is considered safe for use in breastfeeding mothers. It does not significantly pass into breast milk and is commonly used for managing hypertension in postpartum women.

 

Option C. Captopril: Captopril, an ACE inhibitor, is generally considered safe in breastfeeding mothers. Captopril can be used for managing hypertension in a breastfeeding mother, though close monitoring is recommended.

 

Option D. Nifedipine: Nifedipine, another calcium channel blocker, is considered safe for use in breastfeeding mothers. It is excreted into breast milk in small amounts and is commonly used in postpartum hypertension.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Antihypertensive agents with no known adverse effects on infants receiving breast milk: Mnemonic: ECLAM-N
    • Enalapril
    • Captopril
    • Labetalol
    • Atenolol
    • Metoprolol
    • Nifedipine

 

Ref: Smith, M , Waugh, J, Nelson‐Piercy, C Management of postpartum hypertension The Obstetrician & Gynecologist 2013; 15: 45– 50

choices.text: Stop Telmisartan 3 months prior to conception and re-start it at the 3rd month of pregnancy
Stop Telmisartan 3 months pre-conceptionally and start Labetalol
Continue Telmisartan
Continue Telmisartan and add Labetalol if BP is uncontrolled in pregnancy

questions.text: A 37-year lady with chronic hypertension visits the gynecologist for pre-conceptional counselling. She is currently taking Telmisartan for her hypertension. Which is the correct statement?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Stop Telmisartan 3 months pre-conceptionally and start Labetalol

 

  • Preconceptionally, women who are chronic HTN need to be
  • Assesses for ventricular hypertrophy, retinopathy and renal disease
  • Discuss medicine teratogenicity (ACE-I, ARBs, diuretics and beta blockers are contra-indicated in pregnancy)
  • Optimize BP control
  • Switch to an agent appropriate for pregnancy (labetalol, calcium channel blockers)
  • ACE inhibitors and Angiotensin Receptor Blockers (like Telmisartan) cause fetal renal hypoplasia and lead to early onset oligohydramnios as the fetal kidneys are not formed.

 

Let's assess each statement regarding Telmisartan:

 

Option A. Stop Telmisartan 3 months prior to conception and re-start it at the 3rd month of pregnancy: This advice is incorrect. Telmisartan is an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) and is contraindicated in pregnancy due to the risk of causing fetal harm. It should not be restarted during pregnancy.

 

Option B. Stop Telmisartan 3 months pre-conceptionally and start Labetalol: This is the correct answer. ARBs like Telmisartan are contraindicated in pregnancy due to their association with fetal renal dysplasia, oligohydramnios, and other complications. Labetalol is a safer alternative for managing hypertension in women who are planning to conceive and during pregnancy.

 

Option C. Continue Telmisartan: Incorrect. ARBs are contraindicated in pregnancy due to potential fetal risks.

 

Option D. Continue Telmisartan and add Labetalol if BP is uncontrolled in pregnancy: Incorrect. Telmisartan should not be used during pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ACE inhibitors and Angiotensin Receptor Blockers (like Telmisartan) cause fetal renal hypoplasia and lead to early onset oligohydramnios as the fetal kidneys are nor formed and are therefore contra-indicated in pregnancy.  

 

Ref: Page no 438, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: The patient has diabetes
The patient has a urine infection
The patient’s urinalysis is consistent with normal pregnancy
The patient’s urine sample is contaminated.

questions.text: During a routine antenatal visit, an 24-year G1 at 20 weeks gestational age undergoes a urinalysis. The dipstick done indicates the presence of glycosuria. All other parameters of the urine test are normal. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of sugar detected in the urine?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. The patient’s urinalysis is consistent with normal pregnancy

 

In pregnancy, the increased GFR and the impaired tubular reabsorption capacity for filtered glucose occurs; hence glycosuria is a normal finding in pregnancy.

 

Let's explain each of the options :

 

Option A. The patient has diabetes: Glycosuria is a potential indicator of diabetes, but not a diagnostic of GDM and further diagnostic tests like fasting blood sugar (FBS), oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT), or HbA1c may be required to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Option B. The patient has a urine infection: Urinary tract infections (UTIs) can sometimes cause glycosuria due to the presence of bacteria in the urinary tract that can ferment glucose, leading to its appearance in the urine. If a urine infection is suspected, further tests such as a urine culture and sensitivity should be performed to confirm the presence of infection.

 

Option C. The patient’s urinalysis is consistent with normal pregnancy: During pregnancy, some women may develop mild glycosuria as a normal physiological response to hormonal changes. This is known as "physiological glycosuria" and is not associated with diabetes or other medical conditions. It is a benign condition in pregnancy and does not necessarily indicate diabetes. It typically resolves after pregnancy. Monitoring blood glucose levels may still be advisable to rule out diabetes.

 

Option D. The patient’s urine sample is contaminated: Contamination of the urine sample with glucose-containing substances (e.g., vaginal secretions) can lead to false-positive results for glycosuria. Careful collection and handling of urine samples are essential to ensure accurate test results. Contamination should be minimized to obtain reliable urinalysis results.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Physiological glycosuria, a normal response to hormonal changes in pregnancy, may lead to the presence of glucose in the urine without underlying diabetes. It is essential to consider other factors, such as diabetes, urinary tract infections, and sample contamination, and perform further tests if necessary to determine the cause of glycosuria.

 

Ref: Page 66, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Malformations
Polyhydramnios
Obesity
Previous history of macrosomia

questions.text: Which is NOT seen in gestational diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Malformations

 

Congenital anomalies are NOT SEEN with GDM

 

Congenital anomalies are seen Only with Overt DM

 

  • HbA1C > 10 in the 1st trimester: Associated with a higher risk for congenital malformations
  • Most Common system involved – cardiac
  • Most common anomaly seen in GDM – VSD
  • Most characteristic anomaly (very rare)– Mermaid syndrome/ sirenomelia

 

Let's briefly explain the other options:

 

Option B. Polyhydramnios: Polyhydramnios refers to an excess of amniotic fluid in the amniotic sac during pregnancy. It can be a complication associated with GDM, as elevated blood sugar levels in the baby can lead to increased urine production, which, in turn, can contribute to polyhydramnios.

 

Option C. Obesity: Obesity is a risk factor for the development of GDM. Women who are overweight or obese before pregnancy are at a higher risk of developing GDM.

 

Option D. Previous history of macrosomia: A previous history of giving birth to a macrosomic (large birthweight) baby is a risk factor for GDM. Macrosomia is a common outcome of GDM, and women who have previously experienced it are at an increased risk of developing GDM in subsequent pregnancies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) is typically not associated with congenital malformations
  •  GDM can lead to complications such as polyhydramnios, especially if blood sugar levels are uncontrolled during pregnancy.
  • Obesity is a risk factor for the development of GDM and a previous history of giving birth to a macrosomic baby increases the risk of GDM in subsequent pregnancies.

 

Ref:  Page no 1110, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Maternal hyperglycemia leads to fetal hyperglycemia resulting in fetal hyperinsulinemia and related complications
Maternal insulin can cross the placenta resulting in neonatal hypoglycemia
Maternal hyperglycemia results in an increased incidence of congenital anomalies
Fetal hyperinsulinemia results in a lower incidence of respiratory distress syndrome

questions.text: Pederson’s hypothesis states that:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Maternal hyperglycemia leads to fetal hyperglycemia resulting in fetal hyperinsulinemia and related complications.

 

Let's look at each option:

 

  1. Maternal Hyperglycemia Leading to Fetal Hyperglycemia and Fetal Hyperinsulinemia (Answer A): This is true.  Pederson's hypothesis primarily states that maternal hyperglycemia leads to fetal hyperglycemia, as glucose crosses the placenta. In response to this excess glucose, the fetal pancreas produces more insulin. This overproduction of insulin can lead to several complications in the fetus, such as macrosomia, increased risk of birth injuries, and neonatal hypoglycemia after birth.
     
  2. Maternal Insulin Crossing the Placenta Resulting in Neonatal Hypoglycemia (Option B): Incorrect. Insulin, being a large molecule, does not cross the placenta. Therefore, maternal insulin levels do not directly affect the fetus. The hypoglycemia seen in neonates of diabetic mothers is typically due to the baby's own insulin response to high glucose levels in utero.
     
  3. Maternal Hyperglycemia Results in Increased Incidence of Congenital Anomalies (Option C): While this statement is true, it is not what Pederson's hypothesis is about. Poorly controlled diabetes in the mother can increase the risk of various congenital anomalies in the fetus, particularly if the hyperglycemia occurs during the critical first trimester of organogenesis.
     
  4. Fetal Hyperinsulinemia Results in a Lower Incidence of Respiratory Distress Syndrome (Option D): This option is incorrect. In fact, infants of diabetic mothers, especially those with poor glycaemic control, are at an increased risk of respiratory distress syndrome. This is due to delayed lung maturity, partly influenced by insulin's antagonistic effect on surfactant production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pederson's hypothesis emphasizes the direct impact of maternal hyperglycemia on the fetus, leading to fetal hyperglycemia and resultant fetal hyperinsulinemia.
  •  This cascade underscores the importance of strict glycemic control in pregnant women with diabetes to prevent fetal complications, including macrosomia, birth injuries, and neonatal hypoglycemia.

 

 

Ref: Page no 1102, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Caudal regression syndrome is a commonly associated anomaly seen in diabetes
The risk of anomalies in the fetus is inversely proportional to the level of HBA1c.
Folic acid in a dose of 5 mg/day started in the preconception period will not reduce the risk of neural tube defects.
Metformin and Glyburide can be safely continued in pregnancy even though they cross the placenta.

questions.text: A 36-year diabetic woman on insulin is planning conception. She is worried about the risk of fetal congenital anomalies and visits for preconception counseling. Which of the following is the correct statement?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Metformin and Glyburide can be safely continued in pregnancy even though they cross the placenta.

 

  • The most common anomaly in diabetic mothers is congenital heart disease
  • The most specific (albeit rare) anomaly in diabetic mothers is caudal regression syndrome (mermaid syndrome)
  • The higher the HBA1C level preconceptionally; the higher the risk of fetal anomalies
  • Both metformin and glyburide cross the placenta but evidence has shown they are safe

 

Let's analyse each option:

 

Option A. Caudal Regression Syndrome is Commonly Associated with Diabetes: Caudal regression syndrome, a rare disorder characterized by abnormal development of the lower spine, is indeed more common in infants born to mothers with pre-existing diabetes, particularly those with poor glycemic control. However, it's important to note that while the risk is increased, the condition itself is still relatively rare.

 

Option B. Risk of Anomalies Inversely Proportional to HbA1c Levels: This statement is partially true. Higher HbA1c levels, indicating poorer blood sugar control, are associated with an increased risk of congenital anomalies. However, this option is slightly misleading as it implies a direct inverse proportionality, which is an oversimplification. The relationship between HbA1c and risk is significant, but other factors also play a role.

 

Option C. Folic Acid at 5 mg/day Will Not Reduce Risk of Neural Tube Defects: This statement is incorrect. Folic acid supplementation, typically at a dose of 400-800 micrograms per day, is known to reduce the risk of neural tube defects. In some cases, such as in women with a history of a child with a neural tube defect or those on certain medications like antiepileptics, a higher dose like 5 mg/day might be recommended.

 

Option D. Metformin and Glyburide Safe in Pregnancy (Answer D): Metformin and glyburide are oral hypoglycemic agents that can indeed cross the placenta. However, current evidence suggests that they are safe to use during pregnancy and are often prescribed to manage gestational diabetes or pre-existing diabetes in pregnant women. This is the correct statement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • While higher HbA1c levels are associated with increased risks, the use of certain oral hypoglycemic agents like metformin and glyburide is considered safe during pregnancy.
  • Additionally, folic acid supplementation is important for reducing the risk of neural tube defects.

 

Ref:  Page no 1110, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: It is done in the fasting state
Patients with a positive GCT are subjected to a GTT (Glucose tolerance test)
The lower the threshold taken in a GCT, the higher the sensitivity for detection of gestational diabetes mellitus
It is done between 24 – 28 weeks

questions.text: A 23-year primigravida presents to the OPD at 24 weeks. She is advised to get a Glucose Challenge Test done. All are true regarding the glucose challenge test (GCT) except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. It is done in the fasting state.

 

Glucose Challenge Test (GCT)

 

  • Done at 24 – 28 weeks.
  • Plasma glucose is measured 1 h after a 50g glucose load irrespective of prandial state.
  • Value of 
    • ≥ 140 mg/ dl: screen positive: subjected to glucose tolerance test (GTT)
    • ≥ 200: Diagnosed as GDM (No need for GTT)
    • The lower the threshold of GCT, the higher the sensitivity and lower the specificity for detecting gestational diabetes.

 

Let's evaluate the options:

 

Option A. It is done in the fasting state (Answer A): This statement is incorrect, and therefore the answer. The GCT is a non-fasting test. The pregnant woman is given a glucose solution to drink, and her blood sugar level is tested after one hour. The fasting state is not required for this test, distinguishing it from the Glucose Tolerance Test (GTT).

 

Option B. Patients with a positive GCT are subjected to a GTT  (glucose tolerance test): This statement is correct. If the GCT results are positive or above a certain threshold, it suggests the possibility of gestational diabetes, and the patient is then advised to undergo a GTT for confirmation. The GTT is a more comprehensive test involving fasting and multiple blood sugar measurements over a few hours.

 

Option C. The lower the threshold in a GCT, the higher the sensitivity for detection of GDM: This is also correct. Lowering the threshold level for GCT results means more women will be classified as having a positive screen, increasing the sensitivity of the test. However, this might also lead to a higher false-positive rate, where women without GDM are identified as potentially having it.

 

Option D. It is done between 24 – 28 weeks: This is a true statement. The GCT is typically performed between 24 and 28 weeks of gestation. This timing is chosen because gestational diabetes usually develops around this period in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Glucose Challenge Test is a non-fasting, initial screening test for gestational diabetes conducted between 24 to 28 weeks of pregnancy.
  • A positive GCT necessitates further testing with a Glucose Tolerance Test. Adjusting the threshold level of the GCT can impact its sensitivity and specificity for detecting gestational diabetes.

 

Ref: Page no 262, DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition

choices.text: FBS ≥ 126 mg/dL
PPBS ≥ 140 mg/dl
HbA1C ≥ 6.5 %
RBS ≥ 200 mg/dL

questions.text: As per IADPSG recommendations, pre-gestational diabetes is diagnosed in the 1st antenatal visit by all of the values given below except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. PPBS ≥ 140 mg/dl

 

IADPSG Recommendations: Testing in 2 phases

 

1st Phase: To test for overt diabetes (which the woman may be unaware of)

 

  • Done in the 1st trimester (early antenatal visit)
  • Test using HbA1C/ FBS/ RBS
  • FBS ≥ 126 mg/dL
  • HbA1C ≥ 6.5 %
  • RBS ≥ 200 mg/dL (but this should be confirmed by FBS/ HbA1C)

 

2nd Phase: To test for GDM

 

  • Done between 24 – 28 weeks
  • 75g GTT
  • Fasting: 92/ 1h – 180/ 2h – 153
  • Any one value abnormal: Enough to diagnose GDM

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In diagnosing pre-gestational diabetes during the first antenatal visit, IADPSG guidelines include criteria such as a fasting blood sugar of ≥ 126 mg/dL, an HbA1c of ≥ 6.5%, or a random blood sugar of ≥ 200 mg/dL.

 

 Ref: Page 1108, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: FBS < 95 mg/dL, 1h PP < 140 mg/dL, 2h PP < 120 mg/dL
FBS < 90 mg/dl, 1h PP < 145 mg/ dl, 2h < 125 mg/dl
FBS < 105 mg/dl, 1h PP < 140 mg/dl, 2h PP < 120 mg/dl
FBS < 95 mg/dl, 1h PP < 120 mg/ dl, 2h PP < 140 mg/dl

questions.text: Target blood glucose levels for women with gestational diabetes on treatment are:
questions.solution:
Ans. A.  FBS < 95 mg/dL, 1h PP < 140 mg/dL, 2h PP < 120 mg/dL

 

The target blood glucose levels in treatment of diabetes in pregnancy is:

 

  • FBS < 95 mg/dL
  •  1h PP < 140 mg/dL
  •  2h PP < 120 mg/dL

 

These targets are designed to balance the need for tight glucose control to prevent fetal complications while minimizing the risk of maternal hypoglycemia. It's important for women with gestational diabetes to monitor their blood glucose levels regularly and adhere to their treatment plan, which may include diet modifications, exercise, and possibly medication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For the management of gestational diabetes, target blood glucose levels are set to ensure both maternal and fetal well-being. The recommended targets are:
    •  fasting blood sugar less than 95 mg/dL
    • 1-hour postprandial less than 140 mg/dL
    • 2-hour postprandial less than 120 mg/dL.

 

Ref: Page no 264, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition

choices.text: Cut short the 2nd stage of labor
Prophylactic methylergometrine at the delivery of anterior shoulder
Restrict IV fluids
Oxytocin 10U IM following delivery

questions.text: All the following precautions are taken in labor in a woman with pre-eclampsia except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Prophylactic methylergometrine at the delivery of anterior shoulder

 

Precautions to be taken in labor in women with pre-eclampsia

 

  • Restrict IV fluids to avoid pulmonary edema
  • Cut short 2nd stage of labor using instrumental delivery
  • Avoid methylergometrine at delivery of anterior shoulder
  • Active management of 3rd stage of labor including Oxytocin 10IU IM

 

Let's examine each option:

 

Option A. Cut Short the 2nd Stage of Labor: True. In cases of pre-eclampsia, it may be necessary to shorten the second stage of labor to reduce stress on the mother. This can be achieved through instrumental delivery if needed and if there are no contraindications.

 

Option B. Prophylactic Methylergometrine at the Delivery of Anterior Shoulder: This is the correct answer. Methylergometrine, a uterotonic, is generally avoided in women with pre-eclampsia due to its potential to elevate blood pressure. The use of methylergometrine is contraindicated in hypertensive disorders due to the risk of exacerbating hypertension.

 

Option C. Restrict IV Fluids: True. Fluid management is critical in pre-eclampsia. Overloading with IV fluids can increase the risk of pulmonary edema, a complication of pre-eclampsia, especially when there is accompanying capillary leakage and reduced plasma oncotic pressure.

 

Option D. Oxytocin 10U IM following Delivery: True. Administering oxytocin post-delivery is a standard practice to facilitate uterine contraction and reduce the risk of postpartum haemorrhage. Oxytocin is preferred over ergometrine in pre-eclampsia cases due to its lesser effect on blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective

 

Precautions to be taken in labor in women with pre-eclampsia

 

  • Restrict IV fluids to avoid pulmonary edema
  • Cut short 2nd stage of labor using instrumental delivery
  • Avoid methylergometrine at delivery of anterior shoulder
  • Active management of 3rd stage of labor including Oxytocin 10IU IM

 

Ref: page no 440, Textbook of Obstetrics, Dr JB Sharma 1st edition

choices.text: New onset proteinuria
Platelet count < 75,000
Increase in systolic BP by 30mm Hg and diastolic by 15 mm Hg
Fresh retinal hypertensive changes

questions.text: All of the following indicate superimposed pre-eclampsia in a pregnant female of chronic hypertension except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Increase in systolic BP by 30mm Hg and diastolic by 15 mm Hg

 

 

Let's assess each option to determine which one does not indicate superimposed pre-eclampsia:

 

Option A. New Onset Proteinuria: The development of new-onset proteinuria in a pregnant woman with chronic hypertension can be a sign of superimposed pre-eclampsia. It is one of the criteria for diagnosing this condition.

 

Option B. Platelet Count < 75,000: A significant drop in platelet count, known as thrombocytopenia, can be an indication of superimposed pre-eclampsia. It is a concerning feature associated with this condition.

 

Option C. Increase in Systolic BP by 30 mm Hg and Diastolic by 15 mm Hg: This is the correct answer. An increase in systolic blood pressure by 30 mm Hg and diastolic blood pressure by 15 mm Hg from baseline may indicate worsening hypertension in a pregnant woman but does not specifically indicate superimposed pre-eclampsia. Instead, it suggests poorly controlled chronic hypertension or exacerbation of hypertension.

 

Option D. Fresh Retinal Hypertensive Changes: The presence of fresh retinal hypertensive changes is a concerning sign and may indicate superimposed pre-eclampsia

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of chronic HTN with superimposed preeclampsia is made when a woman with chronic essential hypertension develops any of the above maternal organ dysfunction consistent with preeclampsia. Rises in BP per se are not sufficient to diagnose superimposed preeclampsia, as such rises are difficult to distinguish from the usual increase in BP after 20 weeks’ gestation. In the absence of preexisting proteinuria, new-onset proteinuria in the setting of a rise in BP is sufficient to diagnose superimposed preeclampsia.

 

 

Ref: Page no 1780, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: > 4000g
> 4500g
> 5000g
> 5500g

questions.text: Elective cesarean delivery is indicated in a diabetic woman if the estimated fetal weight is
questions.solution:
Ans. B. > 4500g

 

As per the ACOG (to prevent shoulder dystocia)

 

  • Elective LSCS is done in non-diabetic women if the estimated fetal weight is > 5kg
  • Elective LSCS is done in diabetic women if the estimated fetal weight is > 4.5kg

 

The increased risk in diabetic pregnancies is attributed to the higher incidence of fetal macrosomia, often a result of poorly controlled maternal blood glucose levels. Macrosomia increases the risk of complications during vaginal delivery, including shoulder dystocia, where the baby's shoulder becomes lodged behind the mother's pelvic bone during delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • As per ACOG, for diabetic pregnant women, an elective cesarean delivery is recommended if the estimated fetal weight exceeds 4.5 kg.
  • This is in contrast to non-diabetic women, where the threshold for an elective cesarean is set at an estimated fetal weight of more than 5 kg.
  • The lower threshold for diabetic women is due to the increased risk of macrosomia and related birth complications, including shoulder dystocia.

 

Ref: Page 859, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Elective cesarean delivery regardless of the presence of lesions at the time of labor
Vaginal delivery if there are no active lesions at the time of labor
Vaginal delivery with administration of antiviral prophylaxis
Induction of labor at 37 weeks to reduce the risk of neonatal infection

questions.text: A pregnant woman is diagnosed with primary genital herpes infection. What is the most appropriate management regarding delivery?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Vaginal delivery if there are no active lesions at the time of labor

 

Explanation: If a woman has primary genital herpes before pregnancy or in early pregnancy and has no active lesions at the time of labor, vaginal delivery is usually safe. However, if she has active genital lesions or prodromal symptoms at the onset of labor, a cesarean delivery is recommended to prevent neonatal herpes infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • If there is active genital herpes at term, cesarean section has to be done

 

Ref: Page no 673, High Risk Pregnancy: Management Options; David James, Philip J Steer; 5th edition

choices.text: Creatinine levels 1.24mg/dl
Platelet counts 154000/microL
Alkaline phosphatase 142 IU/L
Total protein of 252mg in a 24-hour urine collection

questions.text: A multiparous patient who did not attend any antenatal visit and came to causality with complaint of bleeding. On examination uterine tone was increased with BP>144/92 mmHg. Which of the following tests supports the diagnosis of preeclampsia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Creatinine levels 1.24mg/dl

 

Preeclampsia is a pregnancy specific syndrome that can affect virtually every organ system.

 

Let's assess each option based on the above explanation:

 

Option A. Creatinine levels 1.24 mg/dl: This is the correct answer. Elevated creatinine levels can be indicative of kidney dysfunction, which is one of the organ systems affected in preeclampsia. Kidney dysfunction can manifest as an increase in creatinine levels.

 

Option B. Platelet Counts 154,000: Thrombocytopenia (a low platelet count) can occur in preeclampsia, but this value (154,000/microL) is within the normal range for platelet counts.

 

Option C. Alkaline Phosphatase 142 IU/L: Elevated alkaline phosphatase levels are not a specific marker for preeclampsia. Alkaline phosphatase levels can be affected by various conditions, including liver disorders, but they are not a primary diagnostic criterion for preeclampsia.

 

Option D. Total Protein of 252 mg in a 24-Hour Urine Collection: While increased proteinuria is a hallmark of preeclampsia, the total protein value of 252 mg in a 24-hour urine collection is is less than the cut off of 300 mg.

 

Educational Objective

 

Preeclampsia Definitions

 

Preeclampsia

 

  • Hypertension and proteinuria or
  • In absence of proteinuria, new-onset hypertension with the new onset of any of the following
    • Thrombocytopenia: Platelets <100 x 109/L
    • Renal insufficiency: serum creatinine >1.1 mg/dl or doubling of serum creatinine in the absence of other renal disease
    • Impaired liver function: Elevated blood concentrations of liver transaminases to twice normal concentration
    • Pulmonary edema
    • Neuro: Unexplained new-onset headache unresponsive to medication (without an alternative diagnosis) or visual symptoms

 

Preeclampsia with severe features

 

  • Preeclampsia diagnosis, above, with any of the following
    • Severe hypertension
      • On two occasions at least 4 hours apart while on bed rest (unless already on antihypertensive therapy)
    • Thrombocytopenia: Platelets <100 x 109/L
    • Impaired liver function (without an alternative diagnosis): Elevated liver transaminases greater than twice upper limit of normal or severe persistent right upper quadrant or epigastric pain not responsive to medications
    • Progressive renal insufficiency: serum creatinine >1.1 mg/dl or doubling of serum creatinine in the absence of other renal disease
    • Pulmonary edema
    • Neuro: Unexplained new-onset headache unresponsive to medication (without an alternative diagnosis) or visual symptoms

 

Note: The following are not diagnostic criteria for the diagnosis of preeclampsia or preeclampsia with severe features

 

  • Clinically evident edema
  • Rapid weight gain
  • Massive proteinuria
    • Does not qualify as a ‘severe feature’
  • Fetal growth restriction
    • Expectant management ‘may be reasonable’ if mother and fetus appear stable and no other clinical indication is present that would indicate the need for early delivery ACOG states that while it is important to monitor fetal status, FGR in the setting of all other fetal assessment being within normal limits (e.g., AFV, Doppler)
  • Uric acid
    • Hyperuricemia in hypertensive pregnancy is not a diagnostic marker, but is an important finding as a risk factor for adverse maternal and fetal outcomes
      • Small for gestational age (SGA) infant
      • Prematurity
      • Risk for adverse maternal outcomes if include patients with preeclampsia and risks increase with increasing concentration of uric acid
    • May be warranted in the setting of ‘diagnostic dilemmas’ such as diagnosing superimposed preeclampsia in the setting of chronic hypertension

 

Ref: https://www.preeclampsia.org/frontend/assets/img/advocacy_resource/Gestational_Hypertension_and_Preeclampsia_ACOG_Practice_Bulletin,_Number_222_1605448006.pdf

questions.text: A 25 y woman is planning to conceive. She is unsure of her childhood vaccination status. Which of the following vaccines should she receive before conceiving?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Rubella

  • Pre-pregnancy, if rubella immunization status Is unknown, serological evaluation is done (IgG rubella) and if IgG Rubella is negative, then vaccination with rubella vaccine is recommended.
  • Very important! Conception is to be avoided for 1 month after vaccination with rubella as it is a live attenuated vaccine

Ref: Page no 647, High Risk Pregnancy: Management Options; David James, Philip J Steer; 5th edition

choices.text: Consider termination of pregnancy
Oral Acyclovir, antipyretics, and hydration
IV Acyclovir
Varicella Zoster Immunoglobulin (VZIG)

questions.text: A 24-year G2P1L1 teacher presents at 22 weeks with fever and rash since 2 days. She gives history of contact with a child in her class who had chicken pox 10 days earlier. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Oral Acyclovir, antipyretics, and hydration

Chickenpox in Pregnancy

There are 2 important aspects to chicken pox in pregnancy:

  • Pregnant patient presents with rash (Chicken pox)
  • Pregnant patient presents with contact with a person who has chicken pox, and is therefore at risk of developing chicken pox

Scenario 1: Pregnant patient with rash i.e. she has already developed chicken pox

  • Avoid contact with susceptible individuals, until the lesions have crusted over. This is usually about 5 days after the onset of the rash.
  • Symptomatic treatment and hygiene is advised to prevent secondary bacterial infection of the lesions.
  • Oral Acyclovir should be prescribed
  • Intravenous Acyclovir should be given to all pregnant women with severe chickenpox.
  • VZIG has no therapeutic benefit once chickenpox has developed.
  • Women who develop chickenpox in pregnancy should be referred to a fetal medicine specialist, at 16–20 weeks or 5 weeks after infection, for discussion and detailed ultrasound examination (Risk of congenital varicella)
  • If maternal infection occurs in the last 4 weeks of a woman’s pregnancy, there is a significant risk of varicella infection of the newborn. A planned delivery should normally be avoided for at least 7 days after the onset of the maternal rash to allow for the passive transfer of antibodies from mother to child.

Scenario 2: Pregnant patient with history of contact with a person who has chicken pox

  • Determine if she has been vaccinated against chicken pox or has had the infection earlier (i.e. immunized)
  • IF immunized, nothing further need be done
  • If not sure of status: Do IgG VZV
  • If IgG VZV is positive: she is immunized and nothing need be done
  • If she is IgG VZV negative or she is unimmunized: This means she is susceptible and should be given VZ IG within 10 days of contact.

Ref: https://www.rcog.org.uk/globalassets/documents/guidelines/gtg13.pdf

questions.text: Which of the following infections can cause fetal hydrops?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Parvovirus

  • Parvovirus B19 infects rapidly dividing cells
  • It is cytotoxic for erythroid progenitor cells
  • Parvovirus B19 infections in pregnancy can causes fetal anemia, hydrops and fetal death especially if infection happens within 20 weeks of pregnancy

choices.text: Reassure and advise symptomatic treatment
Prescribe antibiotics
Order Zika virus testing
Initiate antiviral therapy

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman in her first trimester presents with fever, rash, and arthralgia. She recently returned from a trip to a region where Zika virus is endemic. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Order Zika virus testing

 

Explanation: Given her symptoms and travel history, testing for Zika virus is crucial due to the risk of congenital Zika syndrome, which can cause microcephaly and other severe fetal brain defects. Testing is done by detecting Zika virus RNA by PCR in blood or urine. It is vector borne (mosquito).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zika virus in pregnancy

 

  • This RNA flavivirus is the first major mosquito-borne teratogen recognized
  • Zika virus is primarily transmitted by mosquito bite, but sexual transmission is possible.
  • Maternal-Fetal Infection:
    • Zika infection is asymptomatic in approximately 80 percent of adults.
    • It may cause mild rash, fever, headache, arthralgia, and conjunctivitis lasting a few days.
    • The fetus can be severely infected whether the mother is symptomatic.
    • In the most severely affected fetuses, a congenital Zika syndrome has been described that includes microcephaly, lissencephaly, ventriculomegaly, intracranial calcifications, ocular abnormalities, and congenital contractures
       
  • Diagnosis and Management.
    • Laboratory testing for Zika infection is recommended in symptomatic gravidas with residence in or recent travel to areas with active dengue transmission and risk for Zika transmission
    • Serum IgM antibodies typically become detectable within the first 2 weeks and may persist for months.
    • For a pregnant woman within 12 weeks of symptom onset, PCR testing of serum and urine specimens for both dengue and Zika virus RNA is recommended.
    • For women with prenatal ultrasound findings suggesting congenital Zika syndrome, Zika virus PCR and IgM are initially performed on serum and urine. Amnionic fluid PCR may be performed, although less is known about its diagnostic accuracy for congenital infection.
       
  •  Currently, no specific treatment or vaccine is available for Zika infection, although several vaccines are in development

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of Obstetrics 26th edition pg 3107
